newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Sony says East Europe can compete with Asia.
newsitem.headline: Sony says East Europe can compete with Asia.

text.p: Top officials of Sony Corp said in Hungary on Thursday that the company intends to expand in Eastern Europe and finds the region competitive with Southeast Asia.
"We have a strong intention to expand our manufacturing in East and central Europe," Sony president Nobuyuki Idei told Reuters during a meeting for Sony suppliers in Hungary.

Idei did not announce any specific plans for expansion by Sony, which now has east European manufacturing plants in Hungary and Slovakia, but said a quarter of the company's business, or some $11 to $12 billion in revenues, originated in Europe.
"Central and East Europe represents about 10 percent of total European business," Idei said. "So I think a local investment for manufacturing will also accelerate our penetration of these markets."
Jakob Schmuckli, a director of Sony Corporation and chairman of Sony Europa Gmbh, said that on a landed cost basis, Eastern Europe could potentially compete with Southeast Asia.

"Of course Malaysia (one of Sony's biggest manufacturing bases) is huge...but I think it is indicative of Europe as a production base at least for the European market that with the central and Eastern European countries we do have a possibility to compete with a Southeast Asian supply base at least on a landed-cost basis," Schmuckli said.
"We believe with the opening of eastern Europe, definitely Europe has a chance to re-establish itself as one of the global supply bases," he added.

Schmuckli said Sony was still in the initial stages with its 30 million German mark home audio-video plant in Godollo, Hungary, but planned to expand it soon from its current 300 workers to 600 or more.
"We are still on the start-up phase," he said. "So far we have hired 300 workers but we already know we will go to 600 or more. That part is already decided, but from there it will take time."
Asked whether the quality of products at the plant was what Sony desired, Schmuckli said: "It is a bit early to tell.
"It depends on the management and workers at the plant -- if they work well they have the best chance...to move it up" and expand the facility, Schmuckli said.
